John Gillam, Managing Director, Home Improvement and Office Supplies
Stewart Butel, Managing Director, Wesfarmers Resources

plist.p: Welcome to the Wesfarmers Full Year 2010 Results Briefing. Your lines will be muted during the briefing. However, you will have an opportunity to ask questions immediately afterwards and instructions will be provided on how to do this at that time. This call is also being webcast live on the Wesfarmers website and can be accessed from the home page of wesfarmers.com.au.
I'd now like to hand the call over to the Managing Director of Wesfarmers Limited, Mr. Richard Goyder. Sir, please go ahead.

Welcome everyone to this call on the group performance for 2009-2010. I'm joined in Perth by the Divisional Managing Directors and Terry Bowen and each of those starting with Ian McLeod, Coles, who will go through their divisional performance, and then we'll all be available for questions after conclusion of the presentation.

So if you are following, we'll try and sort of give you slide numbers as we're going through the presentation. So I'll kick-off just with an overview of the group performance on slides four and five. And we are pleased to report a full year net profit of $1.565 billion for the 2009-10 financial year up 2.8% on last year, on revenue of $51.8 billion. It's a gratifying result as we had the impact of significantly lower export coal prices on the Resources Division, which reduced that division's earnings by 720 million on the previous year. And the result also includes $137 million after tax of non-trading items. If you exclude the impact of the Resources Division, our EBIT increased by over 31%, with our retail businesses up by nearly 16%, once again showing the strength of diversity of Wesfarmers.
Our operating cash flow was strong, up 9.3% and the Board's declared a full-franked final dividend of $0.70 per share, which takes the full year dividend to $1.25 per share.

Our businesses are running well and we achieved earnings improvements across most divisions last year, with good progress in our turnaround business of Coles, Kmart and Officeworks. Coles achieved encouraging earnings growth and continues to meet our expectations and has made good progress in improving the in-store offer, customer service and trust. Supply chain improvements are well underway and that's enabled us to significantly improve our fresh offer, which is being reflected in sales.

Bunnings had another strong year with earnings and sales growth, and a strong focus on improving customer offer. We've got a very strong pipeline of new stores to open. Officeworks had good sales and earnings growth. Kmart's profit improvement for the year has been very pleasing, and a very strategic reset of the business, which Guy will go through, is well underway. Target's performance was very good, particularly given the more challenging trading conditions in the second half.

In our Industrial businesses, we had a significant fall in resource earnings that I referred to, but importantly all three mines performed well operationally and well placed to take advantage of growth opportunities and higher export prices.

The energy, chemicals and fertilizers division had a better year with strong demand for chemicals, offset to some extent by a difficult year in fertilizers, while most of the energy businesses performed well.
And our Industrial Safety division finished the year well after a difficult first half and that business carries good momentum into this financial year.
Insurance Division had a much better year, notwithstanding some significant claims events, storms, particularly in West Australia and Victoria, with good improvement in the underwriting businesses.

If you move to slide six, that gives you an overview of the Group results. On slide seven, it gives you an understanding of the makeup of EBIT and the increase in retail and industrials and insurance, offset by the fall in resources.
On slide eight is earnings per share and that is lower as a consequence of the higher number of shares on issue effectively, but also shows a dividend payout ratio, which this year is 92%.

On slide nine, I think it demonstrates that we do have a portfolio of strong cash generating businesses and very strong operating cash flow, and strong cash realization for the year, which we are very pleased about and has continued to be a very strong focus in the organization.

Slide 10 has the EBIT numbers for each business, and you can see some really pleasing performances, a double-digit in a number of the businesses over last year, which I've sort of already referred to.

And on slide 11, I'm particularly pleased of the 10 reporting entities there. Eight of the ten improved return on capital for the year. And the Industrial & Safety business is pretty much line ball with the previous year. So again, there continues to be a very strong focus in the Group on return on capital, which is both the earnings and capital employed line in our businesses.
So overall pleased with the performance for that 12 months. I'll talk about outlook at the end of the presentations. But I'll now hand over to Ian McLeod to talk about Coles.

Thank you, Richard. Starting on page 13, as we move from Phase-I into Phase-II of the five-year turnaround plan, we are pleased with our progress and believe this year's financial performance is further evidence that the strategy for Coles is the right one and the turnaround is on track.

Revenue for food and liquor and convenience has exceeded $30 billion for the first time, a 4.2% increase on last year. Full year EBIT was 962 million, up 15.8%. In the second half, EBIT increased 21% as we start to see the benefits of our program to improve efficiency.

For the year, our return on capital improved from 5.5% to 6.5%. Our prudent use of capital demonstrated our sustainable approach for the Coles turnaround. As a result, our EBIT to cash conversion was strong with cash flow for the year of $929 million.

Within food and liquor, despite the transfer of 22 stores to FoodWorks at the start of the year, headline sales still grew by 5.6%. Encouragingly despite a challenging retail environment comparable store sales grew by 5%, faster than the prior year and outperforming the industry.

Given the turnaround strategy is sales-led, this performance is encouraging. However, we also need to recognize the need to improve our costs of doing business and improve profitability both in cash dollars and percentage terms. I am therefore pleased to report a 16.7% increase in food and liquor EBIT and a year-on-year improvement of 40 basis points in EBIT margin to 3.7% for the year.

Within convenience, total store sales grew 5.5% and a combination of fuel and shop sales generated revenue of $6.2 billion, marginally down on last year driven by fuel price deflation. Volumes remain positive. Costs are well controlled, as was the margin mix with EBIT cash dollars increasing to $77 million during the year.

I will now move to slide 14. This years results gives us renewed confidence in our turnaround strategy. In phase 1 we have not only built a solid foundation for future growth for the business, we have also built genuine strength and depth across our senior team with a much higher caliber than 2 years ago.

Further refinement to the operating model will continue, but we are now moving to phase 2 of our plan, delivering consistently well. We have over 100,000 team members, over 2,200 retail outlets across a landmass the size of Europe. The challenge of phase 2 delivery, therefore, is likely to be as tough if not tougher than the improvement performance delivered in the last 2 years. Even though the organization is in a stronger position now to respond to the significant challenge, it will still not be easy.

I'll now turn to slide 15. At the commencement of the turnaround, we knew that we had to engender higher levels of customer trust and value, but we still have more work to do. We have generated strong traction on this dimension. Through a combination of aligning state-based pricing, price repositioning on popular brands, fewer but deeper promotions, redevelopment of Coles brand, and the offer of value meal solution for under $10, value perception at Coles have improved significantly.

I will now turn to slide 16. Although value alone will not drive sales unless we improve quality especially of our fresh produce, we've continued to focus heavily on our supply chain, improved product sourcing, quality control, speed to market and fresh food product care in store.

Food and vegetables for example lands in store an average of 18 hours faster now than they did a year ago. Each of these factors have combined to engender higher levels customer confidence in the quality of our fresh food where sales are now going faster than the average. This is particularly evident in our renewal stores. Standout departments have been fresh produce and in-store bakery and across fresh food we are developing craft skill programs to enhance our skills further.

Sponsorship has also played its part in increasing awareness of the improved quality of our fresh food offer. The fact that MasterChef contestants cooked the fresh ingredients supplied by Coles adds to our growing credibility as a fresh food retailer. Improving in-storage experience is also a key thrust of our strategy as can be seen on slide 17.

Much better focus has been placed on improving our operating standards, offering growth opportunities for enthusiastic and capable managers. 50% of our store managers are new or changed role in the last 2 years. Investing in cleaner, better presented stores better availability, fewer queues aided by roster changes and self-scan checkouts in 78 stores.

Wherever possible we have endeavored to give you the chance as we continue to grow our own internal capability. Our renewal program also continues to provide encouraging results. We have now landed 56 new store formats in just 18 months. And through a combination of new stores and refurbishments, we'd expect that number to almost treble during the course of the new financial year. While the initial emphasis has been on fresh food, we are also introducing new concepts in grocery such as, health and beauty concepts and also books and magazines.

I now turn to slide 18. While our turnaround approach is focused on growing sales momentum, we also recognize that we need to improve our cost of doing business. We are continually seeking ways to improve our operating efficiency and redeveloping our ways of working. Cutting cost is expedient but is not a sustainable option. Our store replenishment program was postponed in the early days of the turnaround as the impact on both working methods and people had not been fully considered.

The rollout of easy ordering began in earnest in the second half of this year and 80% of our volume as a business will be integrated by the end of FY11. Indeed by the end of the month half a fleet will have converted to easy ordering.

We expect to see improved productivity, reduced inventory, improved availability and lower waste and markdowns as a result. In addition, better training improved rosters and changes to contracts have resulted in 22% reduction in absenteeism, and more than 700,000 additional hours worked by our team members at no additional cost.

I'll now move to slide 19 to discuss our liquor and convenience businesses. I will now look briefly at our liquor and convenience businesses. Our liquor business continues to perform well despite the challenge of a contracting liquor market we experienced solid growth in both sales and profit during the year, and encouraging growth in market share. Within our convenience business as a result of fuel price deflation revenues from fuel and convenience softened slightly but investment in forecourts, improved mix of fuel sales such as Shell V-Power and Diesel saw volumes grow in a competitive market.

I'll now like to turn to slide 20 for an overall outlook. In summary, we are encouraged that turnaround plan remains on track, but the job is far from over. Economic conditions remain challenging and whilst food inflation is likely to remain at low levels there are signs that global food commodity prices could be rising.

As we move into phase 2 of our plan, the challenge of delivering consistently well will only get tougher but is a challenge to which we are still determined to rise and look forward to Coles making further progress during the next financial year.
I'll now hand over to John Gillam.

Thanks, Ian. I'll start at slide 23 and comment firstly on Bunnings headline results. Bunnings traded pleasingly across the full year achieving operational revenue growth of 10.4%. That drove an uplift of over 10% in earnings and our trading margin remain strong at 11.4%.

We continue to reinvest both in new stores and in land banking sites for future development. Reinvestment levels into existing stores remain strong. As a result CapEx for the full year exceeded 410 million. And given the CapEx level we were really pleased to maintain our ROC above 30%.

Turning to slide 24, you can see we've reported good cash sales growth for the year of 10.3% with store-on-store cash sales growth of 7.3%. Trade sales lifted by a healthy 10.8%. Growth was achieved from a number of sources; strong work on consumer and merchandizing initiatives, a continued focus on commercial customers, network expansion activities and business improvements.

I'd like to quickly repeat to the supplementary information pack and specifically slide 11 on our comparative sales methodology. Going forward we will be reporting comp sales on a total store basis as opposed to our current reporting of just the cash sales component of a total store performance.

The current method does not take into account the level of trade sales purchase in-store with cash and growth in trade sales activity in our stores is skewing this proxy. That's why we need to change.

Returning to slide 24, the Bunnings network continued to expand across 2009 and '10. We opened 22 trading locations during the year including 11 new warehouse stores, 3 smaller format stores and 9 trade centers. Since year-end we've opened a further 3 warehouse stores as well as new small format store by acquisition.
And as we reported at the May Investor Briefing our new store pipeline is in very good shape. Slide 10 in the supplementary pack contains more detail on network activity.

In terms of outlook for Bunnings, slide 25, we expect continued sales growth with positive contributions from retail and trade. Headline sales growth will be tempered to some extent by the strong focus we have on driving value in the business through our range reset work, which will have some deflationary impact.

Our strategic agenda remains aimed at leveraging 5 growth drivers: Service, category expansion, network expansion, trade presence and business fitness. The rollout of our network in 2010, '11 will continue at the higher end of our stated annual range of 10 to 14 warehouse stores, 2 to 4 smaller format stores, and 4 to 8 trade centers. At the same time we will also maintain a significant investment in the new store pipeline for the longer term.

I'll turn now to the Officeworks performance and status, slide 26. Officeworks' trading revenue for the year was 1.4 billion, an uplift of 8%. Earnings growth of 13% resulted in earnings of 74 million at a better EBIT margin of 5.3%. ROC also improved up by 60 basis points.

Looking at the slide 27, there are a number of highlights for the Officeworks' team across the year. Headline sales growth for the Officeworks retail store network was 9%, a pleasing result. Strong lifts in transaction numbers continue to underpin sales growth as strategic initiatives improving the overall offer continue to gain transaction.

Business channel sales also gained in momentum across the course of the year. What the past 12 months have shown is that we are well on track with the work needed to reinvigorate Officeworks. This has included returning the business to a category killer format with a clear value focused pricing policy supported by stronger service, new branding, a new wide store format and new merchandising categories that include new control LIBOR ranges.

During the year, we opened five Officeworks stores and 12 stores underwent full upgrades with a much larger number of stores receiving minor upgrades. Around one-third of the Officeworks store network is now trading with the new store format. At year-end there were 128 Officeworks stores and 5 Harris Tech business centers operating across the country.

There's also been good progress on actions to improve operational effectiveness. Key achievements across the course of the year included the rollout of the new point of sales system into stores, transition to a new cross-dock PC provider and implementation of a new labor scheduling system.

Looking now at slide 28 and the outlook for Officeworks, sales growth is expected in 2010, '11, an environment of continued competitive pressure on margins and costs. The primary focus remains on good quality execution of our strategic agenda. Ongoing improvements in the customer offer will underpin sales growth. Investments to expand and upgrade the store network may be accelerated and there is still more to do to reduce costs and remove operational complexity. The Officeworks team led by Mark Ward are very well placed to successfully tackle this agenda.
I'll now hand over to Launa Inman.
Thanks, John, and good afternoon, everyone. I'd now like you to go to slide 30 and I'll take you through Target's highlights for the year.

Our operating revenue was 3.8 billion, up 1% on last year, with comparable stores sales down 0.9%, as we cycle the Australian government stimulus. However, despite the difficult trading conditions, the team delivered an EBIT of over 381 million and an EBIT margin of 10%. We anticipated that this financial year would be challenging and competitive; and our margins grew through ensuring that our merchandise mix reflected customers' expectations.

In addition, we had a strong focus on managing our inventory and expenses, which paid off, and hence this result. Our core destination, high margin departments being ladies wear, children wear and baby related products all delivered positive growth for the year. However, sales of electrical items, an area that was a major beneficiary of the stimulus package declined over the previous year.

As many of you know, consumer sentiment was and continues to be affected by potential increased interest rates and the higher cost of everyday living through increases on utilities like electricity and petrol prices. As a result, customers are more focused on value than ever, and as a consequence we have responded particularly in the last 8 months by reducing over 50% of our retail price points on like-for-like product from the previous year. This has been across all our core categories of clothing, footwear and homewares. However, I would like to emphasize though that we have not reduced our quality as that is the key part of our strategy.

In October and May, in the strategic briefings, I am glad to see the work we have doing in improving our supply chain efficiencies. These have been completed and resulted in substantial cost savings, better service to stores and improvements in speed-to-market from point of manufacture. It has also assisted us in using this money saved to reinvest in prices. Although we didn't open as many stores as we would have liked, we did put 7 new stores on the ground during the year, including 1 replacement. However, we did close 3 three stores such as like Box Hill and Reservoir.

We have refurbished 24 stores to bring them up to our company standard and another 13 store refurbishments were commenced and will be basically completed in the next month or so. This financial year we will look to open 5 new stores and refurbish 57. 30 of these refurbishments will be our Target Country stores which are often the major retail stores that they operate, and many of them are due for freshen-up.

As discussed at the May strategic update, we are re-engineering our buying processes. The implementation of these new product design and development capabilities have commenced and will ensure our continued differentiation with the focus being on our core categories particularly clothing. We see this disciplined approach across the business, the key to maintaining our position in the market, which is all about differentiation. And this will really start to be evident in winter 2011.

Aligned to these opportunities to communicate in different ways to our customers, we've planned to increase the use of digital technology including online retailing. The last 6 months have been challenging and competitive and we don't in fact see this improving much before December. As we have responded to customers being extremely value-driven, we are experiencing price deflation across all the categories within our business. Of course this comes with challenges as we need to process and sell more units to achieve the same dollars as last year. So, as a consequence we remain cautious.

However, for all that going on, we will stay true to our strategy as a mid-tier big box retailer offering star value and quality to a broad cross-section of the population, and differentiation is never more essential to our strategy than it is right now and going into the future. So with that, I would like to say thank you and hand over to Guy.

Thanks, Launa. And I'll start on slide 34. For the year ending 30 of June, Kmart recorded revenue of $4 billion representing a 0.5% increase over the previous year and 0.1% decline in comparative store sales. We're very pleased with the EBIT for the year of 190 million, which was 74% higher than last year, bringing the EBIT margin to 4.7%. Also I'm pleasing with the return on capital of 21.8% was reached in comparison with 10.5% in the previous year.
Slide 35 depicts our journey of discovery, renewal and growth.
Moving to slide 36, showing our core strategies around the six P&C and our vision of where families come first for the lowest cost on everyday items.

On slide 37. As we progressed with our strategy, it has very pleasing to see that our customers are responding to the changes that we're making. The shift to lowest prices and the changes customer see in service and in-store environment are all contributing to a lift in transactions. For the second half comparative sales growth of 1.9% was recorded.

Throughout the year, focus through renewal has remained on fixing the underlying financial metrics of the business. The improvement in profitability represents the efforts of exist – of exiting from unprofitable products, rationalizing ranges, reducing the skews and moving away from our previous deep discounting model. Benefits have also been achieved through reduced cost in supply chain and control of non-stored administrative cost.

A continued focus on controlled inventory levels has also helped to improve our working capital management, all contributing to healthy growth in return on capital. Also the Kmart Tyre & Auto business again delivered a strong sales and profit result for last year.

Slide 38; going forward, renewal will still remain very active. Focus will continue on delivering improved customer service, clean and tidy stores and fast and friendly checkouts. Cost benefits achieved today will also be leveraged to ensure we maximize efficiencies in these areas.

As the business transitions to growth, we'll continue to invite our customers through 'Expect Change' with customer engagement being the key priority. Our message is clear and will remain targeted, lowest prices for families on everyday items.

So, whilst we continue to reset Kmart through renewal and growth, there will be challenges along the way. Shifting to less skews of high volume, everyday items will clearly place an emphasis on choosing the right everyday items for our customers.

We will cycle through last year's high-low discounting model for the next six months, which we felt. Increasing sourcing costs and raw material prices will place greater pressure on margins and we expect the retail environment to remain competitive and challenging.
However, we are focused on resetting Kmart for long-term success and remain confident that providing lowest prices on everyday items families will help achieve a successful platform for the future.
Thank you and now I'll hand over to Stewart.

Thanks, Guy. Now I refer you to slide 40. Earnings before interest and tax at $165 million, was 81% lower than last year. This decrease is due to reduced revenue as a result of significantly lower coal prices, lower sales volumes, locked-in hedge losses of $85 million and Stanwell rebate of $156 million.
Depreciation and amortization increased due to increase in asset base following the commencement of the Curragh expansion and the successful completion of Blackwater Creek.

Coal production for the year decreased by 6.6% to 14.1 million tons. Importantly, our Lost Time Injury Frequency Rate at 2.1% was significantly lower than last year due to our continuing commitment to creating an injury free workplace.

I'll refer you to slide 41. Resources highlights for the year included the $286 million Curragh expansion to eight to 8.5 million tons of export metallurgical coal is underway. The Blackwater Creek diversion achieved practical completion, on ahead of budget and time.

And in Q4 financial year '10 Curragh was successful in achieving strong pricing outcomes. 25% of Curragh's volumes remains on annual contracts. Annual contract negotiations resulted in a 78% increase in price. The remaining 75% of volume is now on quarterly pricing with an increase of 70% in Q4. Curragh's cost reduction program is on track with year-on-year cost reductions of 9%.

I'll now refer you to slide 42. As previously stated, the Curragh expansion to eight to 8.5 million tons per annum of export metallurgical coal is underway. A two-week shutdown to tying the new Coal Handling and Preparation Plant to the old Coal Handling and Preparation Plant will occur in early 2011. The expansion is due for completion in Q4 calendar year '11.

I'll now refer you to slide 43. Separate to the existing expansion of Curragh to 8.5 million tons of export coal announced in November last year. We have commenced the feasibility study to further expand Curragh to 10 million tons per annum of exports. This expansion with Curragh side with commissioning of Wiggins Island coal export terminal and Curragh is a foundation member of this terminal.
Coal to underpin this expansion would come from remaining reserve of Curragh plus additional reserves at Curragh West, an exploration program to better delineate these reserves will commence shortly.

Now I'll refer you to slide 44, Bengalla expansion feasibility study. This feasibility study to expand the Bengalla mine is nearing completion. It is proposed to expand Bengalla to 8.5 million tons per annum. 10.7 million tons ROM through two stages. We expect to be in a position to make a development decision on Stage One going to 7.5 million tons per annum in the second half of this calendar year.

I'll now refer you to slide 45 resources outlook. Q1 financial year '11 pricing negotiations have completed with 11% increase on Q4 financial year '10 quarterly pricings. Shipping performance from the existing customers remained strong. We are experiencing the re-emergence of a tight labor market and industry cost pressures. From the 1, of July this year, Premier coal is the sole supplier to Verve Energy.

Curragh's metallurgical sales for this financial year 2010-'11 is forecasted to be in the range of 6.5 to seven million tons and I expect significantly improved earnings from the resources division in financial year '11.
I'll now hand over to Rob Scott from the Insurance division.

Thanks, Stewart. I'll start on slide 47. In 2010, we increased EBITDA by 27% to 131 million or 34% to 122 million on an EBIT basis. This was driven by a strong turnaround in underwriting profitability. Most of our businesses had a positive finish to the year, which resulted in an improved second half result.

Underwriting GWP was slightly down on last year as a result of portfolio remediation and a greater focus on profitable underwriting. Total revenue was marginally below the prior year due to lower interest revenue and FX movements on UK and New Zealand revenues.

The improved underwriting result is reflected in the combined operating ratio improving 4.5 points to 97.9%. Broking operations reported a profit margin of 27.8%, which was slightly down to prior year. It was very pleasing for us that our return on capital improved by 2.3% to 9.1% or 9.8 before amortization of intangibles.

Moving to the highlights, the underwriting result improved by 47 million from a loss of 25 million in the prior year, this was really encouraging for our team given the changes undertaken in recent years to strengthen management, improve risk selection and exit unprofitable arrangements.

A number of headwinds impacted our result for the year. This included severe weather events in Australia, particularly the two major hailstorms, lower investment returns, and losses from the run-off of our builders' warranty portfolio.

It was a year of consolidation in our broking businesses, as we invested in management and systems. Our broking commission and fee revenue increased 3% in local currency terms and was in line with the prior year in Aussie dollars.

During the year, we made some good progress on new growth initiatives. This included a new insurance premium funding solution for OAMPS, the launch of a new corporate underwriting team and EDI solution, both of which are generating good new business volumes for Lumley.

And we've also launched a private major insurance offering through retail partners Kmart Tyre & Auto and Coles. This truly differentiated offer is starting to generate some good interest amongst customers.

Now turning to slide 49 with the outlook; we are focused on maintaining the positive momentum in our Lumley businesses and see opportunities to further improve margins. We've remained very focused on reinforcing the underwriting and claims disciplines that have helped to improve our results to-date.

We are budgeting to increase our investment in IT and to support profitable growth and improve business processes. Lumley New Zealand will go live on a new policy admin system Guidewire, this financial year following the successful implementation of the Claims System.

Commercial premium rate environment remains still quite competitive. Broking earnings will be subject to business confidence and premium rate trends both OAMPS and Crombie Lockwood are well positioned given their scale and resources in what is the fragmented market. We continued to review bolt-on acquisitions of insurance brokers and have a number of prospects under evaluation.
Thanks for your time. I'll now hand over to Tom O'Leary.

Thanks, Rob. Looking first to Chemicals and Fertilizers, the EBIT at 121 million was the combination of the strong earnings contribution from most of the chemicals businesses, partially offset by weak earnings in fertilizers.

In fertilizers, we saw they returned to more normal rate to the applications and sold over 900,000 tons for the year. So notwithstanding the changes to distribution channels, I mentioned back in May, we haven't seen a material change to our market share. And in that respect it lays to a place with the outcome. ROC recovered to 11% from last year's 4.3%, remembering that the last year's earnings were significantly affected by the Varanus Island gas interruption.

Turning to highlights on the next slide; we were able to meet increased demand from the resources sector with production from our ammonia and ammonium nitrate plants increased into record levels. We also had strong sodium cyanide sales particularly of solution into the local market on the back of higher gold prices and increased gold production in Western Australia.

The fertilizers business had been adversely impacted by the rapid decline in fertilizer prices in 2009 and a higher than normal level of stock carried over into 2010. That ultimately led to the 25-million write-down in inventory that was reported at the half. It also led to low margins as we sold through that highly priced inventory.

Moving to Energy on slide 53. The safety performance was disappointing in some areas, so that's a key priority. And change of financial performance, whole energy business units other than Coregas reported improved earnings, contributing to EBIT of 102 million and a recovery of in ROC to 13%, remembering again that the 2009 was affected by Varanus Island.

LPG production was up on last year, and if we turn to the highlights on the next slide 54. It was driven by higher flow rates through the plants with LPG content pretty similar to last year, which I should add though was higher than we'd expected, and higher than we expect this financial year.

In our industrial gas businesses, in WA we benefited from improved conditions, while economic conditions in market demand for Coregas in the East remained challenging. Coregas reported earnings below expectations and the carrying value of that business has been written-down by $48 million. Finally enGen benefited from a full year's contribution from its LNG power stations and is performing well with good growth prospects.

Turning to slide 55 on outlook for the combined division. We are expecting continued strong performances from all our businesses exposed to the resources sector, particularly ammonium nitrate and sodium cyanide, notwithstanding to the sodium cyanide business will face higher gas prices this year.

We're on track to complete our FEED study from ammonium nitrate expansion early next year, and in at this stage that expansion continues to look viable. In claim rate, we're facing increased gas prices in the west from October and we're doing all we can to mitigate that impact.

In fertilizer, we're off to a reasonable start this financial year, despite having been a pretty dry winter in the west. So in terms of outlook, while stronger wheat prices have improved the terms of trade to farmers are returned to more normal levels of fertilizer earnings is still dependant on weather conditions, both over the remainder of this calendar year as well as in the seasonal break in the second half.
I'll now hand over to Olivier Chretien.

Thanks, Tom and good afternoon. I refer you first to slide 57; Industrial and Safety delivered a solid performance this year in a challenging economic environment. Operating revenues for the full-year of 1.3 billion were 1.3% up on last year. Our earnings before interest and tax were 111 million down 2.6% on last year. And our return on capital of 13.9% compared to 14.1 last year and is up from 12.1 at the end of the first half. Thanks to strong capital management across the division. Pleasingly, Lost Time Injury Frequency Rate was 1.6, a good improvement on previous years.
Moving to the highlights on slide 58 and starting with revenues. Our first half revenues were impacted by the slowdown in business activity during the GFC and were down 7.3% on the previous year.

The second half, however, was marked by good sales momentum with revenues up 11% on last year. Improvement in revenues was driven by strong project activity, contracts successes with key customers particularly in the resources sector, very pleasing growth in eBusiness and services as well as increasing industry diversification.
In terms of earnings, our business is facing margin pressures and during the first half our earnings were down 25% on the previous year.

During the second half, however, the pickup in activity and good expense management delivered earnings up 30% on last year. The division also continued to strengthen its capabilities this year, particularly in regards to supply chain and sales effectiveness as well as sustainability.

Now turning to the outlook for the Industrial and Safety division on slide 59. The market conditions have improved and while we are facing ongoing margin pressure, tighter labor market and some global uncertainty, the division is very much focused on growth. Growth is expected to come from four areas, increasing our share of customers' spend in industrial supplies and services, resources and infrastructure based activity, synergies with Coregas as well as acquisition opportunities in a fragmented market.
Thank you. And now I'd like to hand over to Terry Bowen.
Thanks, Olivier, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll discuss the performance of the group's other businesses, as well as key elements of the group's capital management during the year.

So turning to slide 61, profit from associates was $77 million for the year and that compared to a loss last year of $60 million. The major drivers of this result were upward revaluations of the group investment in Gresham Private Equity as the underlying business earnings improved against the prior period.

In addition, we had an improved contribution from the group's investment in Bunnings Warehouse Property Trust. Interest revenue of $65 million was ahead of last year and this reflected the increased funds on deposit in the first half of the year in particular. We recognized a $112 million of non-trading items for the year. These are primarily non-cash in nature and I'll cover those in detail in the next slide.

At the bottom of this slide, other includes the performance of the group's self-insurance program, as well as a number of other small investments. Thanks. Ian, the fingers are pointing at you as the engineer of price deflation in the Australian marketplace in your categories. What you've got in some markets, for example, in milk supply, you have suppliers who have about 80% market share in individual states and if the demand for overseas milk grows they can freeze, dry it and restrict supply here which will cause the price to rise which you don't have an alternative source of supply the way you have elsewhere in Europe.

In some areas where you've got larger suppliers, global suppliers, they – if you dig into their report and accounts you'll probably find that where you can get the information you will find that they make more money out of Australasia than they might make in other areas of the world.
